You have been busy. Your people must be proud.
I see you have fought many battles since the last time we met.
Though time is short, you have no idea where I will attack.
Where is your strength now? We are about to destroy you.
These combined forces can only mean victory for us.
Your skill is impressive. I was sure I had won.
See how easily I crush your inferior warriors.
A fine choice, facing my superior warriors.
Do you see how we are united against you?
Do you not have the courage to face me alone?
What spirit is helping you, that you are able to advance in age so quickly?
You are wise to seek help from the locals, but you will still be defeated.
That will not help you. My brothers are united against you.
You can burn my town, but we will melt into the wilderness and strike back at you.
That trading post was not needed.
It is unwise to linger in the first age. You will have nothing to defend yourself with against my warriors.
You are falling behind. Please, construct a town worthy for my warriors to destroy.
So many resources wasted so soon. Are you up to something?
I hope your ally is able to support you both, since it is obvious you are wasting resources.
You are confident to think you will not need your ally's help against my warriors.
You can build next to your ally's town. It will not help you.
You must be very desperate now that your plans have been stopped.
It makes me feel good to lift the yoke off my Native brothers.
Feel the might of the Sioux.
Another eyesore removed from the plains.
I promise you an honorable death.
It seems you think you are ready for a bigger challenge.
It appears you are still stinging from the last time we played.
I know these lands well. The advantage is mine.
The bleeding you suffered last time seems to have taught you a lesson.
You have much confidence, taking on a bigger enemy.
Your braves cling so close to your war chief. They look scared to be outside your town.
Your warriors seem to be lost.
Come closer. My warriors do not want to travel far to slaughter your army.
Coward! You kill women instead of my superior warriors.
That is an admirable force, but what good are soldiers without a leader?
I see some children have wandered away from your camp.
The spirits favor you with stealth.
Some of your men are lost. Just like their chief.
So that is where you plan to die.
A valiant fight, but that is not yours to take.
Watch how my warriors appear out of nowhere.
Things are quiet out there. My warriors could be anywhere.
I do not know how, but you were the better war chief today.
You were lucky this time, but we will rebuild.
Why do you continue to plead with Natives? Are your own soldiers so bad?
You may have more trading posts, but that only means more glory for my warriors.
You have the speed of a bird, but your bones are just as brittle.
No amount of treasure will keep my warriors out of your town.
You are greedy, like all our enemies.
Eat that food quickly, you will soon be choking on my tomahawk.
All the treasures in these lands will not keep me from spilling your blood.
Your war chief is a long way from home. I hope he knows his way back.
It won't be long before your Native allies have realized that they are on the wrong side.
Keep those people safe, or they will become part of my tribe.
No amount of wood will keep my warriors out of your town.
Walls mean nothing to the Sioux. We will be in your town before you wake to the danger.
My tribe grows while yours sits idle.
See how quickly the influence of my people spreads across the land.
The power of my people grows with every passing second.
This wealth will buy many warriors.
More food to feed my people.
There is much treasure to be found around your base. I'm sure you don't want it.
My treasures pile up, yet you have so few. Is something wrong?
My tribe grows with more powerful warriors.
See how the people flock to my tribe.
This wood will build many huts to house my warriors.
The locals here will soon learn that they have joined the wrong side. Do not count on their help.
You waste your time and resources on ugly buildings. My people will burn them to the ground.
You do not scare me with these tactics. My warriors will soon put an end to this.
My tribe's influence is all over the map. You do not have the power to stop me.
It would appear that another opponent has been drawing your blood. Now it is my turn.
It seems you have been fighting less worthy opponents. Now I will give you a true lesson.
You have been practicing, but wisely not against me.
More sacrifices! The enemy is close to winning!
Cuauhtemoc will play tlachtli with your head if he loses.
Cuauhtemoc's treasure is not at the bottom of the lake. Pay no attention when he tells this to the enemy.
The gods are pleased with the blood Cuauhtemoc has spilled for them. Victory will soon be ours.
The mighty Aztecs do not need artillery. But you do.
Unlike us, you will need siege weapons to destroy the foe. Build artillery.
Train more cavalry. Cuauhtemoc's warriors like the strange, hornless deer.
The mighty Aztecs run their enemies down on foot. But you must train cavalry if you wish to do the same.
You waste blood in that fight - you need more infantry.
The Aztec Empire is built on infantry and blood. Train more foot warriors.
If you insist on sacrificing your warriors, please do so at the temple.
Retreat -- you waste your warriors on the battlefield!
The stones of the battlefield drink the life of your army. Run away until you are stronger.
The battle you enter will be bloody, and while Cuauhtemoc relishes blood, he relishes victory more.
Retreat, the gods are not nourished when your blood is spilt on the battlefield.
Good, our enemies gather together so that we may slaughter them all at once.
Let the blood of our warriors and our foes mix and nourish the gods.
Cuauhtemoc has never garlanded so many so quickly.
Cuauhtemoc has captured many enemies for sacrifice.
An easy victory. More blood for the gods of the Aztecs.
Cuauhtemoc has turned defeat into triumph again!
Our enemies were like the stars, but Cuauhtemoc waded through blood to earn his victory.
The gods favor those who make sacrifice to them. Many lives were lost in that fight.
That fight was too fast. Cuauhtemoc lacked time to capture sacrifices.
Many went to the afterlife, but Cuauhtemoc prevailed.
Cuauhtemoc will have many sacrifices after this battle.
The pipiltin called Cuauhtemoc away for this?!
Cuauhtemoc will crush our enemies in the coming battle.
After the enemy throw themselves on Aztec blades, Cuauhtemoc will return to the temple.
The battle turns. Cuauhtemoc thanks you.
Cuauhtemoc is glad your army arrived. He was beginning to consider the knife for himself.
They enemy bands together! They fear Cuauhtemoc - and they should!
Artillery? What is this 'artillery' you speak of?
Cuauhtemoc will comply as best he can.
What need have Aztecs for artillery? Cuauhtemoc will show you a different kind of 'artillery.'
You joke with Cuauhtemoc, yes? The Aztecs ride no beasts.
Cuauhtemoc will send his fastest warriors.
Cavalry? The Aztecs do not borrow the strength of beasts.
Of course Cuauhtemoc will train infantry.
Infantry? What else from the Aztecs?
What else could Cuauhtemoc train except infantry?
Cuauhtemoc does not like to share.
Rodents and worms have eaten our supplies. Dark times are ahead.
Cuauhtemoc's warriors labor in the fields... they cannot fight now.
No warriors can be spared. Cuauhtemoc has... religious matters to attend to.
There is unrest in the Empire. Cuauhtemoc can spare no warriors.
This is prevented by happenings beyond even Cuauhtemoc's power.
Cuauhtemoc would, but greater forces prevent it.
The greater law does not allow Cuauhtemoc to do this.
Cuauhtemoc's warriors have bled out their lives. Their corpses would be of little use to you.
Cuauhtemoc does not have enough warriors to send.
Ask again later, Cuauhtemoc may have soldiers for you then.
Bah! They have destroyed a Trading Post. They will pay in blood!
Soon the rebel Aztec leader will grovel at Cuauhtemoc's feet, begging for merciful death.
We will grind the British into dust, like so much corn.
Gold cannot save the Dutch from the wrath of Cuauhtemoc.
The French will find that Cuauhtemoc is merciless.
The blood of Iroquois warriors will soon redden the temple steps.
Cuauhtemoc will feed the heaps of Ottoman corpses to his menagerie.
The Russian hordes could not hope to bear up under the might of the Aztecs.
The Sioux and their famous 'horses' will soon be finished.
The Spanish could never hope to defeat Emperor Cuauhtemoc and the Aztecs.
These traitor Aztecs are stronger than Cuauhtemoc expected.
Cuauhtemoc blames you for letting the British thrive.
How did the Dutch become so powerful? Do they also make sacrifices to the gods?
The French do well. Cuauhtemoc can not tolerate this.
Who would expect such strength from the Germans? Not Cuauhtemoc.
The Iroquois surprise Cuauhtemoc with their strength.
The Ottomans are strong... it must be their coffee.
The Portuguese are stronger than expected. Good, Cuauhtemoc needed a challenge.
Cuauhtemoc has learned that the only thing worse than Russians are more Russians.
Cuauhtemoc must admit, the Sioux seem strong in deed.
Even when the Spanish are few, they are powerful.
You advance quickly. Cuauhtemoc should not have lingered so long over his rituals.
Cuauhtemoc must spill blood to catch up. Blood!
Who are you to advance so quickly - a descendent of Quetzalcoatl?
Our enemy seeks allies here. It will end badly. Trust Cuauhtemoc.
Alliances are fragile. Cuauhtemoc is not concerned that our enemy trusts in them.
Cuauhtemoc trusts no one but himself. Let our enemy forge his foolish alliances.
Our enemy has created an alliance for us to break.
There are no warriors in the first Age. Warriors bring death. Death wins wars!
You have spent long enough in the first Age.
Advance in Age or be crushed like an overripe melon.
You are too slow to be worthy of life. Advance or die.
Advance in Age soon - Cuauhtemoc can carry you no longer.
Soon it will be too late. Advance or die.
If you have no use for your villagers, send them to Cuauhtemoc. He has ideas for them.
Why are you so far behind Cuauhtemoc?
You are too fast for us all. Cuauhtemoc is yet mired in the first Age.
Be careful. He who rushes forward exposes his back.
Good. Soon you will have many warriors to bring death to our enemies. You are training warriors, yes?
The omens in the sky whisper of your greatness.
You are the first to advance in Age. Now death shall reign among our foes.
Finally you have caught up with Cuauhtemoc.
You had better not be so slow again. Cuauhtemoc cannot always protect you.
You are slower than the sloth in Cuauhtemoc's menagerie.
Finally. Does your heart beat as slowly as you advance in Age?
Cuauhtemoc will make sacrifices in your name so you can advance in Age more quickly next time.
Cuauhtemoc has saved us all. You are welcome.
They are broken! Now Cuauhtemoc goes for the throat.
No alliances! Cuauhtemoc does not allow them!
Cuauhtemoc has broken the enemy Native alliance here.
Now these Natives may consider an alliance with Cuauhtemoc. He would like that. Very much.
Out! Out! Cuauhtemoc has chased the enemy from this village.
Cuauhtemoc reigns over this ruin in darkness and smoke.
Smoke and fire! Our enemies flee Cuauhtemoc.
Cuauhtemoc will take many captives from the enemy colony.
Cuauhtemoc's warriors dance in the rubble of our enemy's town. Slay them, my warriors! Slay!
They shall not trade here anymore. So says Cuauhtemoc, Emperor of the Aztecs.
There can be no trade if Cuauhtemoc forbids it.
Come! Build a Trading Post here. Cuauhtemoc commands it.
Why did the enemy fools think that any would want the goods peddled here?
If a building can be sacrificed, Cuauhtemoc has sacrificed this Trading Post.
Bah... Cuauhtemoc could not destroy our enemy's alliance with this tribe.
Cuauhtemoc must regroup to attack the Trading Post in the Native village again.
Emperor Cuauhtemoc cannot be defeated... yet he was.
Cuauhtemoc has discovered that our enemy's buildings are protected by dark magic.
Unbelievable. This Trading Post somehow survived Cuauhtemoc's attacks.
When will this Trading Post fall to the might of the Aztec Empire?
What incompetence! Cuauhtemoc's war chief has fallen.
Someone or something has slain Cuauhtemoc's war chief. The gods found him unworthy.
The water is bitter. Our food is bitter. Nothing can save Cuauhtemoc.
Send an army here or you will find only gloriously-fallen Aztec corpses.
The city is in flame. All is darkness and destruction. Can even you save Cuauhtemoc?
Quick! Send your armies to Cuauhtemoc's city!
Cuauhtemoc's city shall soon fall. When it does, your city may follow.
I am Cuauhtemoc. Cuauhtemoc is the Aztec Empire.
I am Emperor Cuauhtemoc. The Aztecs stand ready to conquer.
Cuauhtemoc does not want to hear your cries when the enemies attack with fury in their hearts.
Perhaps easier enemies shall be more to your taste. They certainly are to Cuauhtemoc's...
How have you been since last we met? Since you crushed Cuauhtemoc's people under your heel.
Cuauhtemoc bows before no one save the gods... are you their messenger?
Hmmm... Cuauhtemoc wonders if you will be better now than when last we met.
Cuauhtemoc can not carry you this time. Stand on your own or die.
We do like battling here, don't we?
The blood spilled this time had better not be Cuauhtemoc's.
Once more we bring battle and bloodshed to our enemies! Death!
My war chief has returned, like Quetzalcoatl. But without the fangs. Or feathers. Or divinity.
Their colony is undefended! Strike now, while their bellies are exposed!
Cuauhtemoc sees no army in the enemy city. Perhaps they have all been fed to the gods?
The enemy has not built any barracks... either they are foolish or they have built it elsewhere. Cuauhtemoc suspects they are foolish.
There is no barracks here. Why anyone would not want Infantry mystifies Cuauhtemoc.
The scouts of Cuauhtemoc have found no stable. Our enemy may have given up on the strange horse-beasts.
Cuauhtemoc sees no stable. Good. Those 'horses' make Cuauhtemoc... nervous.
Take this gold. Do not waste it.
Gold from the coffers of the Aztecs.
Gold, jade, and furs. These will bring you Coin.
This tribute is backwards. You should be sending Coin to Cuauhtemoc.
Grain, fruit and cocoa for Cuauhtemoc's friend.
Cuauhtemoc has sent you a treat - the flesh of captured warriors. Ha! Cuauhtemoc makes a joke!
A gift of food. Could you spare a villager to assist in a teeny-tiny sacrifice that Cuauhtemoc needs to make? A small one will do.
Cuauhtemoc is unaccustomed to sending tribute. Here - take your filthy food.
Take these animal carcasses. They are bled dry.
Here is some wood. Cuauhtemoc builds in stone.
Here is some wood. Carve Cuauhtemoc a mask. What? You use it for buildings? For weapons? What a waste.
What need does Cuauhtemoc have of mere Wood? Take it.
After you get this wood, have your carpenters make a tzompantli so you may display your skulls.
Wood for your fires and your buildings. But especially your fires!
Cuauhtemoc's heart beats strongly - he marches to war!
Cuauhtemoc will capture many for sacrifice after the coming battle.
Cuauhtemoc can already hear the screaming...
Aztec muscle will flatten this base as if it had never been.
Watch the settlers flee... run settlers run! You cannot escape the knife of Cuauhtemoc!
There will be nothing but smoldering grass and rubble when Cuauhtemoc is done with the enemy's town.
Aztec thews will reduce the enemy's town to rubble. And its people to corpses - or captives!
Cuauhtemoc no longer suffers the alliance of this minor tribe with our enemies.
Burn! Burn! There can be no trade without Cuauhtemoc's consent. Burn!
Cuauhtemoc does not trust your wisdom, but he shall fight alongside you.
Cuauhtemoc thinks your ranks look a little thin. His warriors will come to fill them out.
Cuauhtemoc does not want to miss the coming bloodshed. Wait for his army!
The Aztec armies will group here. Get out of the way.
The walls of Tenochtitlan are bursting... Cuauhtemoc is founding a new city.
Begin the songs and music to bless the new city of the Aztecs!
I shall make a great ritual! My new city can not bless itself!
Though he has been burned in the past, Cuauhtemoc shall attempt an alliance with the Natives here.
Cuauhtemoc will speak with these Natives. If they do not agree to ally with him he shall slay... er... he means that he will ask again, nicely.
Cocoa, fine cloth, precious metals... sacrificial animals... all for sale at this new Trading Post.
Cuauhtemoc thinks it is time the world beheld the splendors of the Aztecs. He shall construct a Trading Post.
Cuauhtemoc's soldiers shall defend this building. Or die trying.
Cuauhtemoc will defend this building no matter how many lives it costs.
Cuauhtemoc will hold this area for 52 years!
Cuauhtemoc's warriors shall fight here. They shall die here. Cuauhtemoc himself shall die here if he must.
Cuauhtemoc fights for this alliance. These Natives have proven loyal. Their hearts are strong.
Cuauhtemoc shall not let the enemy sabotage his alliance with these Natives.
The enemy shall not set foot into this town until the last of Cuauhtemoc's warriors are dead.
Cuauhtemoc shall defend this town until the sun no longer rises.
Mighty Cuauhtemoc does not need the goods traded here, but he shall not deprive you of them.
This Trading Post shall stand. So says Cuauhtemoc, Lord of the Aztecs.
Coin? Take it. What do the gods care for gold? They want lives!
My people, we will send gold to our ally. So says Cuauhtemoc, Emperor of the Aztecs.
Warriors toiled long in the fields for this food. Do not waste what Cuauhtemoc sends you.
The chinampas overflow with food. Cuauhtemoc shall send you his leftovers.
Cuauhtemoc requires little Wood. You may have what he does not need.
Cuauhtemoc's people will be cold tonight.
Cuauhtemoc's warriors rush to battle. The thunder you hear is their feet!
Cuauhtemoc sends all the warriors he can spare!
So many sacrifices, so little time.
If you had to choose between your own life and the sun never rising again, which would you choose? Cuauhtemoc is not evil. He allows others to be selfless.
Come to the next renewal ceremony, Cuauhtemoc will spare no expense to... entertain you.
Sometimes Cuauhtemoc imagines that he controls little men, no bigger than his thumb. He makes them scurry and fight and die. Cuauhtemoc needs to lay off the Ololiuhqui.
Cuauhtemoc needs gold. Send Cuauhtemoc coin!
Send Cuauhtemoc whatever coin you feel he is worthy of. He will not be at all angry if it is too little... not angry at all...
Food! Cuauhtemoc demands a feast of food!
Cuauhtemoc needs wood to build a fire on the chest of a warrior sacrifice.
Cuauhtemoc needs wood to burn sacrifices-- er... to build buildings and weapons.
Cuauhtemoc is grateful for your help in slaying our hated enemy.
Cuauhtemoc had the situation well in hand. He needed no help.
Cuauhtemoc did not ask for your help.
Cuauhtemoc shall not waste this gift of coin.
This food shall nourish Cuauhtemoc's people. Cuauhtemoc thanks you.
The Aztec people are grateful for your assistance.
Finally you arrive. If you had not shown up when you did, Cuauhtemoc would have been finished.
Cuauhtemoc did not need your warriors. But since they have marched so far it would be a shame for them to leave.
Cuauhtemoc, Emperor of the mighty Aztecs, thanks you for your fitting tribute.
Ahh.... Good. This wood will burn in the hearths of the Aztecs. The fire god will be pleased.
No! It can't be! No traitor Aztec chieftain could defeat Emperor Cuauhtemoc!
Bah! The British! Cuauhtemoc spits on them!
These Dutch, they are not all about Banks and trade...
Cuauhtemoc hopes the French are as merciful as they are strong.
How could we stop the Germans? Their uhlans run amuck!
Cuauhtemoc fears that the Iroquois have more surprises in store.
Strong artillery. Strong infantry. Even strong coffee! The Ottomans are unstoppable.
The Portuguese crush us... Cuauhtemoc did not seek this much challenge.
We are doomed by relentless Russians.
The Sioux and their cursed steeds! We do not have long.
Who would have expected the Spanish to defeat the Aztecs so easily?
No! Cuauhtemoc refuses to believe his pathetic Aztec rival is beating him! It is not so!
Cuauhtemoc has made sacrifice after sacrifice. And still the weak British prevail.
How do the Dutch defeat Cuauhtemoc?
The French are winning. The only answer to this humiliation is blood! More blood!
Cuauhtemoc must not allow the Germans a victory. Though it may be out of his hands.
The Iroquois slaughter us. Cuauhtemoc is unaccustomed to being on the pointy end of the knife.
If the Ottomans were more powerful they could end this now. Instead they make Cuauhtemoc linger.
How! How can the Portuguese beat us? With numbers? With gunpowder? Hmm... that is probably it.
The Russians drown us, but how? Cuauhtemoc blames you.
The Sioux are not worthy of beating Cuauhtemoc. Yet they do. Perhaps using these 'horses' is not so foolish after all.
No! The Spanish are so few! How could they possibly defeat Cuauhtemoc?
Cuauhtemoc can stomach no more blood. Cuauhtemoc is so funny. He loves blood. But we are losing.
We are losing. How can a king be as weak as you?
Blood flows down the temple steps! We are winning!
Cuauhtemoc has concealed his power well. Now the victory seems like your doing. No thanks necessary.
This victory is Cuauhtemoc's, but you may bask in his reflected glory.
Come with Cuauhtemoc to the temple. It is time to end this war.
Emperor Cuauhtemoc wishes to end it. The obsidian knife is ready.
Cuauhtemoc can fight no longer. He will be unsuitable for sacrifice if the fighting continues.
What will convince you to stop? Should Cuauhtemoc hand you the obsidian knife?
Look - a glowing ear of corn in the sky - it sheds sparks like drops of blood... this is a sign. It is over.
Cowards! They fear to face Cuauhtemoc's armies at the time of his choosing.
The enemy allies with the Natives here. Cuauhtemoc cannot allow this.
Cuauhtemoc refuses to let the enemy monopolize trade here.
They build alliances with the Natives. They are out after Cuauhtemoc!
Good. Cuauhtemoc's foes are denied that tribe's loyalty.
Bah, why bother with Trading Posts?
Your first treasure. Take it as Cuauhtemoc's gift.
Cuauhtemoc thinks you are out to get all the treasures... yes... all the treasures.
Cuauhtemoc could have used that coin.
Cuauhtemoc could have used that food.
Fine! Take all the treasures! Leave none for Cuauhtemoc!
When you have no more use of that Native, send him to Cuauhtemoc.
Villagers? Take them. Cuauhtemoc wants warriors.
The more Native tribes we ally with, the fewer our enemies have to turn against us.
Cuauhtemoc hopes that you spending resources on your army too. Fruits and blankets make poor weapons.
Cuauhtemoc hopes that you have enough wood to train warriors after building that wall.
Cuauhtemoc cannot leave the Natives here to ally with his enemies.
The mighty Aztecs share their goods with the world.
Cuauhtemoc finds treasure in the wilderness.
This treasure in your town must be tribute for Cuauhtemoc.
All the treasures of the wilderness are tribute to Cuauhtemoc and the Aztecs!
Cuauhtemoc has rescued a Native, who will make a fine scout.
Cuauhtemoc has rescued villagers...hist! Cuauhtemoc can hear their beating hearts.
This wood will make fine maquahuitl.
Cuauhtemoc cares not for alliances, but better Cuauhtemoc than his enemies.
Cuauhtemoc, Emperor of the Aztecs, Master of Trade!
Walls... the better to keep Cuauhtemoc's people safe.
We will win if enough time passes - Cuauhtemoc shall begin offering hearts to the gods for our victory!
No defeat is so great that it cannot be washed away by blood.
Cuauhtemoc sees you have won battles since we met. He celebrates with a sacrifice!
You grow more experienced with each battle. Cuauhtemoc offers thanks to the gods.
One of these Trading Posts must fall!
Cuauhtemoc will feed your souls to the hungry gods.
Cuauhtemoc was wrong about you. You would make a fine sacrifice.
Bah! Sacrifice at the temple is one thing, but on the battlefield...
Cuauhtemoc cannot lose! This must be an evil dream sent by the gods.
You are no challenge to mighty Cuauhtemoc.
Cuauhtemoc can feel the blood of your people running down his arms already.
What made you think that battle was a good idea?
Cuauhtemoc asks... do you prefer a slow death or a swift one?
You may flee... Cuauhtemoc is not without mercy. Who is Cuauhtemoc kidding?
Your warriors have turned the battle. Cuauhtemoc wonders what you shall demand for your help.
Cuauhtemoc's enemies band together. They fear him!
Rush headlong into death! Cuauhtemoc awaits.
What? Already you advance in Age! This displeases Cuauhtemoc very much.
Bah... Cuauhtemoc does not fear you, why should he fear your allies?
Do not think you can turn these Natives against Cuauhtemoc!
This town is destroyed, but Cuauhtemoc will find another lake and another cactus and another snake-eating eagle.
Cuauhtemoc did not need that Trading Post.
Are your people too frightened of Cuauhtemoc to advance in Age?
You are still in the first Age? Perhaps Cuauhtemoc will ensure you never see the second one.
Cuauhtemoc wonders why you cling to such primitive ways.
Cuauhtemoc's warriors are stronger than yours. His farms are more productive. His carpenters are more skilled. What hope do you have?
When you rush ahead, Cuauhtemoc has a good shot at your back.
Young corn grows quickly. Cuauhtemoc will cut you down.
Welcome to the wars. This is the Age where Cuauhtemoc will begin to destroy you.
Aha! Cuauhtemoc told his ally you were still here. His ally did not believe him.
Your town is far from everyone else... no one can hear your screams...
Bah! After he crushes your town Cuauhtemoc has a long walk to destroy your allies.
Ah... good. After Cuauhtemoc destroys your town he will not have far to march to finish your ally.
Try again and fail - again! So says Cuauhtemoc.
Cuauhtemoc cannot suffer these alliances to exist.
Your colony is destroyed - Cuauhtemoc brings death to his enemies! And his friends.
None may trade without Cuauhtemoc's say.
I am Cuauhtemoc, Lord of all Aztecs. And you are not Quetzalcoatl.
Ahhh...It is a fine day for Emperor Cuauhtemoc to nourish the gods by sacrificing your warriors.
Kneel before Emperor Cuauhtemoc and he will let you choose the manner of your own death.
I am Cuauhtemoc, Emperor of the Aztecs. Cuauhtemoc will enjoy placing your skull in the tzompantli.
Last time we met, Cuauhtemoc was distracted. This time, he will cut you and your pathetic colony to ribbons.
It is good to admit weakness. Perhaps you should just hand yourself over to Cuauhtemoc for sacrifice right now.
You must enjoy spilling your blood in this land. So does Cuauhtemoc.
Stacking the odds in your favor? Cuauhtemoc sees that your efforts are fruitless.
What? Cuauhtemoc was not enough of a challenge? He does not need a new ally to defeat the likes of you!
Cuauhtemoc's war chief returns. He lusts for vengeance.
You will not gather many treasures with him.
Cuauhtemoc has spotted your warriors. The gods thirst for their blood.
No, no, the temple is over here. Attack near it so Cuauhtemoc will not have far to drag the bodies.
Why do your warriors attack Cuauhtemoc? Has some war begun he did not know about?
No one spills the blood of Cuauhtemoc's people except Cuauhtemoc!
Cuauhtemoc sees you have come to negotiate your surrender.
This army is too small to conquer me, but almost too large to capture for sacrifice. Almost.
Your warriors scurry like insects in Cuauhtemoc's' city. Ow! Stinging insects!
The blood of so few can only cause the sun to rise for a week or two. Send more.
Cuauhtemoc has discovered your pathetic colony.
It is good of you to leave tribute for Cuauhtemoc. He will make your death as painless as he can.
Cuauhtemoc cannot resist warning you of his attack so he may smell the fear in your sweat.
That thunder? It is the blood rushing in your ears that you hear.
The Aztec army comes. Surrender so that Cuauhtemoc can more easily take you to the waiting altar.
A sign glows in the sky, an ear of corn shedding sparks like blood.
There is always room for sacrifice.
Cuauhtemoc concedes. The treasure of the Aztecs is at the bottom of the lake.
Give Cuauhtemoc an honorable death so that his blood may nourish the gods and his flesh feed your menagerie.
Before you cut down Cuauhtemoc's people, would you care to share a cup of chocolate?
Burn the bridges! Pour the treasure into the lake! The Aztecs are finished.
No! Cuauhtemoc will never surrender! Unless you let him...
Cuauhtemoc did not shed enough blood to ensure victory. It is the end of all things.
The Aztecs are defeated. Will the sun ever rise again?
Trade cannot save your pathetic colony.
Those treasures cannot save you from Cuauhtemoc's obsidian blade.
You amass wealth. All the more for Cuauhtemoc when he conquers you.
Your collection of treasures may comfort you in the grave.
Cuauhtemoc will enjoy making you pay for stealing that treasure.
Be careful of treachery from those you protect.
Run villagers! Run to your savior's colony!
Gathering wood for your funeral pyre?
Cuauhtemoc sees a wall. You are properly frightened.
No wall can save you from Cuauhtemoc.
The Aztecs are well known for their alliances with neighboring peoples.
Cuauhtemoc claims all trade in this land.
This land is ripe with treasures that belong to Emperor Cuauhtemoc.
Cuauhtemoc laughs at your sluggish treasure gathering.
Cuauhtemoc loves the Natives of this land.
These villagers are hearty. They will work hard.
A cache of wood, the better to burn you with!
In Cuauhtemoc's experience, such alliances can be deadly. Enjoy!
A Trade Post. Now Cuauhtemoc knows where to find you.
If you cannot defeat the mighty Aztecs on the battlefield, why do you think this will work?
Good, my warriors like a challenge. It gets the blood up.
Cuauhtemoc's victory is immanent. If you surrender now, you will have the honor to be the first at the altar.
Cuauhtemoc opens the gates to his city so you may view its splendor as you die.
Cuauhtemoc thinks that perhaps you have been seeking treasure at the bottom of a lake.
You climb the steps to glory. Cuauhtemoc waits at the top.
Do not imagine that Cuauhtemoc will cower just because you are more powerful than when he last faced you.
Fear for us, O ally. Harm and evil come now near us!
Better were it to go fasting than to bear this dreadful burden - we stand to lose in less than one minute.
A monstrous story; we are but one minute from losing this war.
Do not fear for me, O ally. Harm and evil shall come no more near us!
By the shining water and the drifting grass lands, we shall win in less than one minute.
From my brain the thought of vengeance, but from my heart the simple need for more siege.
It would be a great achievement if you could bring more siege weapons to this battle.
In these days of evil spirits, the fields of battle need more horsemen from you.
We fight onward, in solemn manner, and need from you more horsed warriors.
When I speak to the foe he trembles, the need in battle is for more foot warriors.
Our war clubs are swinging, our foes are cracking, but to win the war we need more foot warriors from you.
You are like a man from a dream awakened, only to face a terrible blow. Withdraw, my ally, withdraw.
The shattered sky above us breaks! Do not join us in this doomed fight, my ally!
A battle rages. The sky we tread beneath bends and throws itself in fury.
We join and raise our fists against the heavens; a great battle rages here!
The clouds are swept from heaven. By our hand the enemy has passed from the fields, as we expected.
The tens and eights of our enemy have fallen in that battle, as I knew they would.
We threw them on the ground before us, our foes in rows vanquished.
A moody melancholy takes me, with this victory that once seemed unlikely.
Curious eyes stare about us. How did we win that battle, which should have been a loss?
In many games of skill and hazard, one would have to reach far to find a battle like this one. How did we win it?
Mighty move our forces, our foe's heart shall be swept with ice.
I enter this fray full of eagerness.
This battle will be excellent, full of victory for us and defeat for them.
We shall circle our foes with confidence. They shall lose this fight.
Timely and potent your arrival. The tide of battle flows now in our favor.
It is good you are back from your wanderings; you are needed to turn the flow of this battle.
Enters through the door a burning firebrand; another foe has joined the fray.
The enemy has seized the war club in this fray; we may fare poorly.
This is where we agree, yes.
On my nation, on my honor, yes.
Ay, though panting under heavy burdens.
Ay, the forges shall fire, the siege made.
I shall build the siege weapons you need, ally.
Ay, our horse riders shall tread, and the grasses bend.
You shout for horse riders, and horse riders I shall give you!
Beneath shaggy eyebrows, I gaze. Your horse riders are on their way.
Ay, although to the land of ghosts and shadows they may walk, foot warriors we shall train.
The foot warriors shall journey to your side.
Yes. And loosely shall our foes be scattered, when my foot warriors arrive to help you.
Our supplies and resources are little more than smoke wreaths. I cannot comply.
My reserves are too low to meet your need, ally.
I have not the food, wood, nor coin to help you.
To your request, we cannot accede.
The fallen leaves of last year... No.
Have your eyes been blinded by the dark and bright? I have no warriors to help you.
You must find strength within. I lack an army to help you.
Alas. I cannot. Better were it to go fasting than to bear such a heavy burden.
Although the eyes of wolves glare at me, I cannot do that.
My young soldiers are insufficient in number to meet your request.
My forces are too depleted. No.
I have too few warriors to help you now.
Enemies have journeyed to one of our trading posts. It is laid to waste.
We cannot win that way after all.
The Aztecs have traveled a long and weary journey, but it looks now finally to be at a dark end.
The Aztecs have almost been destroyed.
Not so long and wide the world is... my wrath has reached the British empire!
The British are almost gone, as ducks in the winter.
If the powerful Dutch go on thus, we shall tear them to pieces.
With fiery eyes and screaming, the Dutch fall before our war hatchets.
For days the French have journeyed the pathways of the dead, and now they have reached their end.
The French fought as well as they could, but are nearly lost.
The Germans are almost gone to the land of ghosts and shadows.
Their leadership in tatters, the Germans crumble before us.
We see before us the false Iroquois, their warpath broken before them. They are all but defeated.
Our false Iroquois foes are forced to the edge. They cannot fight much longer.
The Ottoman foe passes now, heavy laden under our blows.
The ravens tell me that nothing the Ottomans can do will save them now.
The Portuguese tread the solitary path to defeat and ruin by our hand.
Our Portuguese foe is falling. Soon his form will mingle with the crushed grass.
Slowly vanish the Russian foes to the land of the hereafter.
The Russians appear to have lost the war here.
The earth shall be covered with silence; our foes are almost done with.
The Sioux must return to their gloomy plains. We have nearly defeated them.
To our Spanish foe lies now only a pathway to the lonely end.
I see that the Spanish are doomed.
How much power they bring to bear, the Aztec empire is thunder upon the soil.
My eyes watch with awe. The Aztecs are a mighty foe.
If outrageous Britain goes on thus, tearing everything to pieces, what becomes of us?
It is a wonder that any nation has stood against our powerful British foe.
Never stoops the soaring Dutch bird, mighty of wing and sword.
The Dutch have a strength on the battlefield like a mountain bear.
Disasters come not singly. The first descends from the French, but others will follow.
A hawk with talons sharp and strong, the French descend with force most awesome.
The powerful Germans have pressed us as if stooping over a ground bird's nest.
We dare not taunt or provoke our German foe until we have grown as strong ourselves.
Ever wakeful, ever watchful, the Iroquois warriors seem mightier than the trees.
The Iroquois empire is mighty on the lands, moving like a strong river through the woods.
There are corpses clad in garments, ghosts that come to haunt us. The Ottoman are a mighty foe.
The Ottoman foe has great power in these lands. We dare not fight them too soon.
We are thrown down before them. The Portuguese may tramp over our downed weapons with ease.
The Portuguese are fierce sea hawks. They are not to be trifled with.
The Russians laugh like water, their power in war rolls over the earth.
Our foe from Russia has mighty hordes. Perhaps more than we can answer.
Never once have the Sioux, by a movement of their troops or sign of might, appeared anything but strong.
The Sioux might slay us, if we are not fully prepared for their strength.
We strove to seize the finest land, but the Spanish press back and may win the day.
The Spanish have great strength. Let us not be blinded to this truth.
I endure in silence, as you journey up the ages ahead of me.
You have climbed the great tree of time, advancing well before I could.
Our enemy claims the rights of guest and stranger in these lands, taking a Native settlement.
Our enemy has gone like fog off the water, and claimed a Native ally.
You are late in your arrival to the Commerce Age, my ally.
Are you waiting for the ducks to return for the summer?
Do not weep in the silent midnight, instead make haste and advance to the next age.
Stop drifting on the stream of time and advance to the next age.
You have pushed aside the deerskin curtain, walking into the Commerce Age before anyone else.
You have landed first on the shore of the Commerce Age.
Has perchance my ally grown old, waiting to advance to the Commerce Age?
It is good you have joined us in the Commerce Age, o slow one.
Henceforward and forever, I shall speak to the winds my thanks to you.
I cry aloud and speak like sunlight: you have rescued my war chief.
I have moved heavily upon their trading post in time.
The enemy were a threat, but I have torn their plans to bits.
The trading post in the Native village has been struck down. Forthwith and forever.
My warriors have struck. An enemy Native village has fallen like an dead tree.
See the masses of the enemy, lying still in their valley.
Dust and broken arrows alone remain, in the enemy town I have just visited.
An enemy trading post has been destroyed, souls sent upon their journey.
Hear me ally. I have crushed a trading post of our hated foes.
The trading post at the Native village still stands, although our outrage moved upon it.
The enemy was too strong. I could not invade that Native village.
We did fail in the lesser trial; the enemy town still stands.
We ran to ambush the enemy town, but we were forced back.
I report to you news unpopular; the enemy trading post stands yet.
My warriors moved with heat and silence but were unable to strike down that enemy trading post.
Night approaches, let a grave be kindled. My war chief is dead.
I cannot capture treasures from the wilderness without my war chief.
A guardian in the wilderness has killed my war chief.
My war chief has fallen early, defeated by a creature of the wilderness.
I faint in the harder struggle, feel a looming darkness over our hope.
The cold breath of fate flies to us. I cannot see how we can win.
My warriors need help in this place.
I need help in the distance. Here.
I see my nation scattered, forgetful of my counsels. I plead my ally's help.
Enemies swarm like bees in my town; too many to fight without help.
I am as a guest in your wigwam, my ally.
Greetings. We shall rise in power together, like the new moon.
Together we shall send our foes to haunt the fen-lands.
Oh the blasting of the fever! The wasting of the famine! The challenge you have set is terrible but fair.
The challenge will be greater now.
The hungry stars in heaven watch over our contest, set lower in difficulty than our last battle.
You have changed the difficulty. You desired to float easier in the waters of war.
We are allies now, but in our last contest you were as the great bear of the mountains, and defeated me.
When we last met, you sent me to defeat, dark and lonely.
Your score in our last meeting was exceptional. But we are allies now, and shall triumph as one force upon the land.
In the last war we were allied, you fielded a mighty army. It was luminous.
We were enemies, and the unseen spirits call out my victory. We were enemies but now fight as one.
Allied forces we were in our last battle. But my score was the mightier by far.
This realm looks familiar. These north winds sweep over the same battle lands we fought in last.
We were allied forces in our last battle, but it was as though we laid asleep and cumbrous, and lost the day.
Last time we fought as a team, but the trail was long and unsatisfying.
Honor be to my ally! We came in triumph in our last contest, and shall walk again the same now.
It was good to battle by your side before. Let's walk the same path to glory again.
I have paid the price twas due, so my war chief may again swing aloft his club.
I will not let fear overcome me. I have paid the price to return our war chief to us.
Our war chief has been returned to us.
He was once lost, our war chief, but my warriors have just rescued him.
I have rescued our great war chief.
Shout loud your war-cry! I have seen the enemy's town center and no army is there.
Alert your forces. I have seen the enemy's town and it lies undefended.
Our enemy's town center has no barracks near it.
There is no barracks in the shadow of our enemy's town center.
The enemy Town Center is under my gaze. I see no stable standing near it.
The enemy is without a stable in his main town.
Coin runs into your coffers, a tribute from my own.
Spend this coin wisely, my ally.
Your town has been given a gift of coin.
Food I grant you - feed your forces.
Food from our maize fields, green and shining.
Wood has been sent. Wood for your houses of war.
Here is wood from our homeland forests.
We move to smite the enemy; break his skull, as ice is broken.
The enemy has drawn me to him. I prepare to attack his base.
We send raiders sneaking through the forest. Their gatherers shall be dragged down by our claws.
The enemy gathers, and now I raid him.
We will move now as the great bear of the mountain, the terror of the nations, to attack the enemy's main town.
The enemy's main town is ripe for assault, like sugar from the maple.
The enemy's allied Native village shall tremble as a reed, for we stomp to it with heavy step.
This Native village belongs to the enemy. It stands between us and victory.
We are strongest; we shall attack a trading site.
I send word to you, ally. I prepare to attack this trade site.
Standing fearlessly with you, my warriors will join in your siege of this enemy site.
I will join you in this attack.
Cease not your attack. As a biting wind I shall fly to fight by your side.
This is where my military base shall be planted, and grow as a terrible thistle grows.
I shall spread my power over this clearing, and build the buildings of war.
This is my claim. The area I shall make my base.
My town center shall rise and hold to this ground, as a root to the earth.
This is my next town center location.
The trees will witness it; a new town center will arise here.
We shall raise our war clubs over a Native village, and claim it as our own.
We lie low in ambush, to soon gain the help of these Native warriors.
Our armies shall be strengthened with these Natives, as claws on the cougar.
The winds of heaven blow over us, and we have decided to claim a trade site.
We come with caw and clamor, and will capture a trade site.
The fog lays on the river, but none upon our heart. We shall defend this building.
This building is important to me. It will be guarded well.
Not even a ghost that goes at sunrise shall halt us in our goal. We shall defend this place.
We shall stop them here, with all our craft and cunning.
We will defend this Native settlement to the end.
Our foe may croak fiercely his displeasure, but we shall defend this Native settlement to the end.
The forests and rivers around us shall know what we do this day -- this town shall remain defended.
Our enemies will not struggle past us. We will hold this town
Hear us, ally. We sing and shout this news. We defend this trade site.
This trade site belongs to us now, and no foe shall take it under this sky.
As the cormorant and curlew, returning always to their nests, we shall continue to send you coin.
The coin will continue coming to you from our coffers.
Food will continue to arrive to you, my ally, as the river flowing silent but strong.
I will keep sending wood, the grass of giants.
Wild and wailing, my warriors shall come to fight alongside you here.
We run through the forests to help defend this site.
Hold the line, my ally. We will join you in the defense of that site soon.
Must I shout down the smoke flue, to remind you of my presence?
One day we will be done with fighting. But that day is not today.
I greatly need you to give me some coin.
Maize or meat, it matters not. I ask only for any food you can give me.
It is odd, but we of the forest need to request wood of you.
Our breath comes sharply to our nostrils; we thank you for joining in our forward fight.
A mysterious darkness awaited us, if you had not entered that battle and saved our heads.
We needed your help as the tree needs sunlight and rain.
Bless you for the gift of coin.
Thank you for the golden gift.
Bless you for your gift of food.
The food you sent was better than we dared hope.
Blessings upon you for helping to draw a circle of protection around our base.
We thought the great death serpent was sliding close, but you came and saved us.
Food from your fields, coin from your coffers, timber from your forests - thank you for these things.
You are a valued ally. Thank you for the resources.
Your gift of timber is good. Thank you.
Wood is what we needed. Timber is power.
What will protect us from destruction? The Aztec enemy is so mighty!
I fear the serpent of death approaches. Our Aztec foe is very great.
What will protect us from destruction? The British enemy is so mighty!
The British are like magicians, creating armies from the very soil. We are losing.
What will protect us from destruction? The Dutch enemy is so mighty!
The Dutch have poisonous exhalations. We grow weaker before them.
What will protect us from destruction? The French enemy is so mighty!
The French move like a blazing serpent. We are losing the fight.
What will protect us from destruction? The German enemy is so mighty!
Do the Germans have fiery breath? Our armies are wiped out before them.
What will protect us from destruction? The false Iroquois are so mighty!
We are losing to the false Iroquois nation!
What will protect us from destruction? The Ottoman enemy is so mighty!
The Ottoman are defeating us. Their armies are so powerful.
What will protect us from destruction? The Portuguese enemy is so mighty!
I feel we are losing. The Portuguese have a mighty stature in battle.
What will protect us from destruction? The Russian enemy is so mighty!
The Russians are too powerful. We appear to be losing this fight.
What will protect us from destruction? The Sioux enemy is so mighty!
The Sioux enemy steps on us as if we were ants on the ground. I fear we are losing.
What will protect us from destruction? The Spanish enemy is so mighty!
The Spanish empire has great strength. I fear we may be crushed before their might.
Our death song may have begun. But there is hope; the Aztec foe is wounded and weak.
Our death song may have begun. But there is hope; the British foe is wounded and weak.
Our death song may have begun. But there is hope; the Dutch foe is wounded and weak.
Our death song may have begun. But there is hope; the French foe is wounded and weak.
Our death song may have begun. But there is hope; the German foe is wounded and weak.
Our death song may have begun. But there is hope; the Iroquois rebels are wounded and weak.
Our death song may have begun. But there is hope; the Ottoman foe is wounded and weak.
Our death song may have begun. But there is hope; the Portuguese foe is wounded and weak.
Our death song may have begun. But there is hope; the Russian foe is wounded and weak.
Our death song may have begun. But there is hope; the Sioux foe is wounded and weak.
Our death song may have begun. But there is hope; the Spanish foe is wounded and weak.
Heed these words, my ally. You are yet strong, but my own blood is now flowing swiftly from me.
Far and wide among the nations will my fall be told, and I may yet drag you down with me.
The rush of death's wings can be heard over the treetops. I fear it is searching for us both, my ally.
The enemy is treading us down like blades of grass.
We stand terrible and strong against our foes at this time.
Our foes cannot hope to compete with our strength.
We have the advantage in this war, and you are the stronger bear between us.
The enemy is envious, we are winning and you have grown strongest of all in this war.
Our war clubs are ruling the battlefields, with my own club raised highest of all.
We are audacious, overbearing, heartless. We are winning and my army is strongest of all.
I fear we may be fighting a battle in which courage but not hope remains.
We are being driven back. Our cause may be lost.
The claws of the enemy sink into us; soon we will be nothing but scarecrows ragged in the wind.
By the spirits of the water, our foes conspire to murder us all.
The skill and wiles of our enemy have taken us, ground us and destroyed us. We cannot win.
There is no hope for us now. We fight on as a blade of grass against an oak tree.
Our foe has claimed the buildings he needs to win. We must rise and answer him at once.
The enemy has enough buildings to claim victory. We must conspire to prevent this.
I have grim news; our enemy has claimed the first Native trading post site.
How quickly our foe has moved to claim a Native ally.
Our enemy plots mischief; they have claimed the first trading route site.
Very smooth and quick he has acted; our foe has claimed the first trading site.
This is good; you have taken the lead in claiming Native sites.
We cannot wait motionless in the sleeping shadows, as our foe continue to claim buildings.
The marauders have grasped the lead in trading sites.
There is drowsiness in the air, but we must not sleep. The enemy has taken the lead on trade sites.
You plot wisely. You have claimed a Native site before any other in the land.
Your vision is clear. If we have Native allies, no one shall stand before us.
You lead the flock, swooping to your claim of the trade site before any other.
Our empire is expanding with your claiming of that trading site.
You are swift; you have gathered a treasure before anyone else.
In the battle for treasures, you have dealt the first blow.
Every small thing adds to the greater whole of our eventual victory.
You are gulping down treasures as a frog gulps flies.
The coin you have discovered in that treasure gleams as an omen of our success.
More coin means more strength, my ally.
The treasure opens, and food for you has been found within it.
I witness that you have discovered a fine treasure of food.
I croak fiercely my displeasure; you are gathering treasures too swiftly for me to keep up.
Do I have a drowsiness in my bones? I cannot gather treasures as fast as you.
Careful, my ally. Treasures near my base are precious to me.
That treasure was in the very shadow of my war encampment.
That treasure has given you new warriors. Long may they fight.
You have found a treasure of warriors, armed and waiting.
A treasure has granted you villagers.
Put those villagers to work on your lands.
Wood from the tall trees, brought low for our use.
Timber from that treasure will help our cause.
We have the advantage in Native allies now, thanks to your efforts.
You have claimed more Native allies than our foes.
You have given us the lead in trading route sites.
Your actions are as swift as the falcon. You have another trade site.
Like the beaver's dams of trunks and branches, you seek to hold back the flood of our foe.
Walls will defend you well, but your warrior's hearts are the greatest defense of all.
I have claimed the first Native site.
We have allied with more Native peoples of the lands.
None have claimed a trade site but I.
Like a meadowlark upon a grasshopper, I clutch this lonely treasure.
Hear me roar like a wintry tempest as I claim another treasure.
I have discovered a treasure, with a treasure within it.
I am gathering only that which belongs to me.
An opening in the forest has revealed a treasure, and within it a savory morsel.
I have passed through your base and tidied the land of a discarded treasure.
You did not want the treasure near your war encampment, did you?
As if vanishing into the forest, you are far behind me in gathering treasures.
Perhaps a morning will dawn in which you have gathered as many treasures as I.
I have discovered a fine treasure; foot warriors who shall join my army.
This treasure has yielded a villager.
A treasure has given me another villager to help expand my power.
Wood has been found, and I am glad.
Like the rushing wind, I have taken a trade site.
Heed my words of wisdom; we need to continue claiming trading sites.
I am building walls to protect us.
I am constructing walls, the enemy shall not blow over us.
We deserve a headdress of bright plumage, for we have claimed enough trading posts.
We must prepare for a response, now that we hold the buildings we need to win.
A clamor rises in my heart; I see that your rating is much lower than last time we met.
Why has your rating dropped so low? Have you been stooping among the lilies instead of fighting?
You are a wonder. How did you raise your rating so high?
I struggle to regain my balance, as I look upon how much more experience you have.
I will whisper to the leaves and blossoms, the wonder of your great increase in experience.
We are nearly dead among the shouting people. We have only a minute left to live.
Do you not hear the warning? We are within one minute of the end!
I hear the voices of triumph coming nearer. In one minute we will win.
Hear my words of wisdom; we will soon win this war!
So long and rough the way of battle, when several tribes have entered the fray at once.
This battle shall be toil and trouble.
How did that occur? We were strong, bold, yet you still defeated our army.
The war spirit promised us a victory. You made the war spirit a liar.
I rent your army into shreds, just as we knew it would be.
We have shown you the death dance.
My armies fly higher than the moon, and cast your warriors beneath the soil!
You are like a small canoe, to be dashed against my rocky headlands.
Look upon these battlefields, my enemy; look at the pathway of your ghosts!
Full in sight my ally has arrived. The waves of war splash now in my favor.
Running straight across the heavens, my ally enters the fray just in time!
The battle is slipping from my grasp like dust and leaves that swirl away.
Your ally bought warriors, with plumes and war clubs. This battle is going foul.
I gaze into a cavern dark and dreary; the news that you have advanced so soon ahead of me.
Dash to advance, dash for the moon. Either way, your empire will crumble before mine.
I see you have claimed a Native site, but I care not.
How did you fool those Natives into following you?
One of my Native sites has been struck a blow, with dark thunder I have lost it.
You strike boldly, but that structure was but a trifle to me.
My town center has tumbled to rocky ruin.
The smoke from the town center you have crushed blots the sun.
Your mischief is unwanted; my trade site has fallen by your hand.
With the destruction of that trade site, you have caused my anger to burn.
I submit that your time of wild adventure is over; will you ever advance from the Discovery Age?
Hurry and advance, and join the fray.
Where are your tricks and gambles now? Or are you too upset to advance in age?
Are you so confident that you think you can defeat me from the lowly age you rest in now?
The tempest of my wrath shall overtake you.
What good is advancing an age, when your army's bones will soon be nourishing the grass?
Welcome to the Industrial Age, oh chief of flying leaves and swirling dust.
If your plan is to watch my empire advance beyond yours, it is working.
A great windy waste separates your town center from your ally's. You will be lonely in death as well.
Your location is far from your allies. It is good for quiet meditation, or your peaceful destruction under my war clubs.
Your bases are huddled like robin chicks in a nest. We shall light your tree aflame.
Your town is so close to your allies. Another mistake to learn from.
One of your Native sites has been destroyed. You will not win the war that way.
Your Native site has been destroyed, tossed in gusty tumult.
The Natives you had joined with are done with you at last.
I cast your people into confusion.
You don't need that town center where you are going.
Through your teeth you buzz and mutter, as I destroy your trading site.
Did you sing a death song for your fallen trading site?
I cast to you words of anger and resentment. There shall be no peace between us.
All my warriors gather around me, and together we send you a greeting of doom.
The challenge level in this contest has been increased. It will not affect the outcome.
Last time we met we had a challenge, yet you wish to increase it even further?
The difficulty level in our last battle left you trampled you like the grass.
Your courage melts, as well it should before my armies.
We have battled in these lands before. Regardless of the outcome then, this time my wrath shall overtake you.
Although the odds may be more to your liking this time, the results will still leave you battered and bruised.
We will pound you as maize is pounded.
You beat my war chief almost to death, but I have rescued him.
I see the movement of your patrol as if through streaming sunshine.
I have glimpsed your army. My heart holds only pity for you.
I see the army you have fielded, puffed with pride, but so soon to fall.
Your children appear to be wandering lost in the wilderness. I will put them out of their misery for you.
The troops you have sent near my town will be beaten if they come nearer.
Your army near my town shall sing the song of fear, when they encounter my own.
Your attack on my villagers is craven, o cowardly foe.
My villagers have no interest in dying. Cease.
I will crush the skulls of your warriors, and you shall bear them home on travois made from branches.
Your large army has wandered aimlessly into my lands. Retrieve it.
Your warriors are wandering far from their homes. Best to retrieve them before they are cut down as grass.
Your army looks wild and wayward. I will help it find its way.
Your army's shadow has darkened the gateways of my base.
What is this army doing in my war encampment?
Your small army is like flotsam in a soiled river
Teach your soldiers to walk where they are wanted, far from my lands.
Your town center is like a duck awaiting my arrow.
So you are found. Next comes the song of destruction.
A small mishap has befallen you; I have won in our struggle for this treasure.
Both of us reached for that treasure, but your fingers returned to you with nothing.
My army has arrived to crush you like pond reeds.
My warriors are here, just in time to wring the life from you.
It is too quiet. I yearn to hear shouting from the forest; a whir and beat of pinions, anything.
This silence is like ice on a lake, waiting for a fishing hole.
Have you lost all hope? Your silence should not surprise me.
Too swift of foot and strong of tomahawk are your warriors. I admit defeat.
This war is nearly done. I am ready to fight no more forever.
You have made it impossible for us to win that way.
Like a swift arrow, you have taken the lead on claiming sites.
You may have taken the lead here, but the race is not yet decided.
It matters not at all that you have gathered the first treasure in this land. I shall gather the true prize; victory.
While you are rushing for treasures, my warriors are learning to fire two arrows to your one.
Enjoy squirreling away your treasures. They will be well enjoyed by my invading warriors.
You are dressed for travel and armed for hunting, and the best you can come up with is a few coins?
The mound of food is the biggest triumph you are likely to enjoy today.
Enjoy the food from that treasure. You may have found your last meal.
What good will your treasures do you if your head is rolling on the grass?
You dared to steal a treasure close to my base. We dare to place a living coal where your heart is.
The treasures around my base are yours if you can get them. However, the land under your base is mine.
You have discovered some warriors to help you. A grim day for them.
I wonder: will that warrior flee from battle with the rest of your army?
You have crossed the rushing rivers, climbed the ancient mountains, only to gain a villager?
The sticks of wood you have gained from that treasure will surely bring glory and fame to your empire.
I see the walls you are lifting up around your base. Like bits of ice, before my summer sun.
A wall may stop the breeze, but it cannot stop the tempest that is my wrath.
My dominion of the land and all of its inhabitants has begun.
Under my wise leadership, I am the first to bring the people of the land together.
I am like Ishkoodah, the comet. I have claimed a trade site before anyone else.
The path of the trading route runs through my empire, now.
I have gathered another treasure, and it has filled me with joy.
The treasures of the wilderness are mine for the taking.
Gaze upon my skills. Another treasure is mine.
I have gained coin from a treasure.
This food will help build the strength of my warriors. From the way yours fight, you must be feeding them bark.
There was a treasure near your base, but it is there no longer.
Treasures are flowing into my coffers like drifting snow in a blizzard. It must be summer in your tiny kingdom.
One more warrior to bring cheerful harm to your empire.
The villager I have discovered will take me one step closer to cleansing this land of you.
We will send the wood we just discovered right over. As arrows.
If you think you have cast fear into our hearts because you have claimed a Native site, you reason like a cattail.
While you were stretching your hand to pluck that trade site, my warriors were training to sever the arm it is connected to.
The clock has begun to count. We shall chop off its hands.
We have begun the clock. You have nothing left but to despair.
Your rating is lower than a groundhog's basement.
How did you raise your rating to the clouds? No matter, I will bring it back to where it belongs.
You have improved, but it is still as though you hope to walk to the moon.
Your experience has increased. Surely your abilities have not kept match.
Hands unseen begin to shake. In moments all shall be taken from us.
It is as if we slew the great bear of the mountains.
Good! The fewer buildings Custer has, the fewer soldiers we will face.
Good work! Keep destroying these buildings.
Only two more of Custer's buildings are left.
With his buildings destroyed, Custer will not bring much to the battle.
A black powder wagon has arrived. Run it into a weapons cache to clear a pass.
A covered wagon has arrived. Use it to set up a town center.
The resources from the Trading Posts would help you defeat Holme.
Run a Black Powder Wagon into a Weapons Cache to open a pass.
As you work your way toward Crazy Horse, you will likely find Black Powder Wagons in the enemy towns.
Failed to retrieve version response from the server. Please check your Internet connection and try again.
Failed to communicate with ESO. Please check your Internet connection, restart the game and try again.
Andes: mountainous region with several Inca villages.\nNatives: Inca\nOutlaws: Desperado, Renegado
Maya barbed spearmen. Good against cavalry, Shock Infantry and buildings.
Zapotec warrior armed with a shield and a sword.
Cherokee long-ranged infantry that is accurate at long range.
Cree rifleman with a good line of sight and long range.
Native American archer. Good against heavy infantry and light cavalry.
Nootka warrior armed with a wooden club.
Cheyenne horseman armed with a spear.
Comanche light ranged cavalry. Good against shock cavalry and artillery.
Ship carrying massive amounts of Coin, but has no attack.
It is time for us to pull our own forces together. If we don't, the enemy will win.
We must hold the line for a few moments longer. If we can, we win.
I look forward to battling you again, when you are ready to fight... instead of building pathetic trade posts.
You are about to win with your trade monopoly. I suppose you think this is a great achievement, but it is not.
I suppose you should send your army to the next war you fight. We are about to win this one with our trade monopoly alone.
We are about to win this war, and it is all the more glorious because we will win with a trade monopoly.
We have suffered a strategic blow. Our trade monopoly is no more.
I have sad news. We have lost our trade monopoly.
Your trade monopoly has been easily stopped by my army. Do you have any other ideas?
It appears that your trade monopoly has crumbled into dust. How sad.
Our enemy seeks to win with a trade monopoly. Needless to say, this effort will end in failure.
Warning, my ally. Our enemy has just started the trade monopoly timer.
We have started the trade monopoly timer. We need only defend it, and win.
I am glad to report that our trade monopoly timer has just begun. We will win soon enough.
Your trade monopoly will crumble before my mighty soldiers.
How do you expect your trade monopoly to stand before my armies?
You will taste a new flavor of defeat soon. We have just started the monopoly timer.
The trade monopoly timer has started, and it is not your monopoly, my enemy.
It is almost the end for the Aztec war machine.
The Sioux were a worthy foe, but their time on this battlefield is just about over.
I admit newfound respect for the mighty Aztec empire. They are kicking our hindquarters.
We cannot stand before the Iroquois. They are too powerful for us to fight.
The Sioux are truly a mighty empire.
These Aztecs are too strong. We will fall beneath their onslaught.
The Iroquois are a mighty opponent - too mighty for us to defeat, I'm afraid.
How could the Sioux be so powerful? We are losing.
The Aztecs are weak and can be defeated if we attack them together, but even then I'm afraid we will lose this war.
Together we can destroy the Iroquois, but I'm afraid the war as a whole is not ours to win.
Why don't we just team up against the Sioux? It is clear we will not be winning this war anyway.
If we cannot attack their trading posts now, perhaps it is time we consider getting our house in order.
We are sixty seconds from losing. Shall we surrender now and spare ourselves the ignominy, or shall we make one last push to overthrow the enemy's trade monopoly?
We shall win a glorious victory, if only this timer would hurry up!
We are sixty seconds from victory! Let us enjoy the final moments of this contest by watching our enemy writhe in the agonies of his failure.
Just one minute before our triumph, my friend! It may be a bit premature, but let me congratulate on a game well fought.
It seems there is nothing I can do to keep you from winning. But there is still a little time for me to take action.
Put away that bunting, I haven't given up yet!
That clock does not scare me; we still have some time.
Tick tock. Hurry now, but not too much. Haste makes waste.
Oh my, we are close to victory, aren't we? Hahaha.
Rule, Britannia! Britannia dum de dum...
How annoying. Now we have to start the countdown all over again.
Well... it was fun while it lasted.
Haha! Now you will have to start over again.
Take that! And expect it again, just as good!
There. Now, we can have a stand up fight. I will not tolerate any more of your tricks.
The enemy has a trade monopoly! We have to act fast!
Oh no. We'll need to get our act together, and quickly!
Look sharp now, we have work to do. Let us be about it!
Now all we have to do is sit back and wait for victory to fall into our laps.
Time brings victory to the patient. Would you join me for tea?
The fight is not over yet. Your timer does not mean we are finished.
Oh dear, now I suppose I shall have to send my armies to annihilate you. And we were having such fun.
My lobsterbacks know just how to deal with your trading posts!
Hear that? The clock is ticking now. Just a few short minutes and you lose!
Oh dear, what is that I hear? Why it's... it's your defeat approaching. Tick tick tick.
Look at the timer. Tick, tick, tick. The countdown to doom.
The Aztecs do build lovely cities. Too bad they will soon lie in ruin.
A gallant fight from the Iroquois. I am almost sad to see them defeated. Almost.
The Sioux will soon be defeated. More's the pity.
The Aztecs are arrayed in their finest regalia, a fearsome sight indeed.
The Iroquois are strong and growing stronger.
Though we may not understand their ways, we should not underestimate the Sioux.
I had never thought to see any stand against our alliance. Alas! The Aztecs not only stand, they tower!
The Iroquois cannot be stopped, I fear.
I'm afraid the Sioux are going to be our undoing.
The Aztecs are close to defeat! Let us make one last grand rally and take them with us!
The Iroquois cling to a thin thread. Perhaps we can cut it before we are defeated.
With our last breath let us take battle to the flagging Sioux!
If we cannot attack their trading posts now, then it is indeed over.
I told you that trust in me was well-placed. We are close to victory.
We have persevered this time, my friend. Ottoman goods and diplomacy have won again!
There is still time for me to snatch victory from the lion's mouth.
No matter where you go, your destiny follows you. Yours has followed you to the brink of defeat.
He bites his tongue who speaks in haste. Do not crow your victory from the hilltops yet.
I have persevered, and soon I shall be rewarded.
If skill could be gained by watching, then dogs would be butchers. And you would be a general.
One already wet does not feel the rain. You, my friend, are soaked in failure!
They have destroyed one of our trading posts and stolen away our well-deserved victory.
We were so close to victory, my friend. Perhaps we should try again.
Thorns and roses grow from the same root. The rose you have found will soon show you its thorns.
That is quite enough of that!
An open door invites enemies. Forgive me for walking through yours and crushing you.
Your children's grandchildren will not look back on this defeat with shame. No, not at all.
We should have known they would try to win this way.
Victory does not come so easily as starting a timer. Who buys cheap buys dear.
They have chosen to be the nail rather than the hammer. Poor choice.
A red apple invites stones. Our prosperity will make us a target. We must prepare.
We have chosen to be the anvil rather than the hammer. Our patience will outlast your strength.
Patience is bitter, but it bears sweet fruit. Now the waiting begins.
My armies will crush the victory you seek. But where will they strike?
There are many places you must defend. But where will Suleiman attack?
You cannot hold two watermelons under one arm. How do you expect to keep all those trading posts?
My victory is inevitable. Surrender and I will treat you and your soldiers to a feast in my colony.
The moment of my victory approaches. I can hear the bombards sounding.
I am sure your children's children will be able to forgive your coming defeat.
The Aztecs rival the Ottoman Empire in grandeur, though not for much longer.
The Iroquois alliances are shattered and their time at an end.
Fierce though they were, the Sioux are nearly finished.
I can see smoke rising from the Aztec temples, but I do not believe the cities are burning. This makes me uneasy.
The Iroquois are like lions - we had best keep a close eye on them.
I hear hoofbeats in the distance - the Sioux are not idle. We must be wary.
The Aztecs drain our strength like spilled blood.
The Iroquois have proven stronger than our alliance.
My ally, our mistakes catch up with us like the swift hoofbeats of Sioux warriors.
We can discuss our many missteps later, with wine, over a proper meal, but now before we lose, let us attack the Aztecs one last time.
We are in poor shape, but so are the Iroquois. Come, my ally, let us march on them one last time.
The Sioux are weak, but we should be able to defeat them. There is no shame in small victories.
Only one minute! Inconceivable! Attack, attack, attack, for we are at the critical moment!
Ha! We have them now. One minute left before our enemy's total humiliation!
Just one short minute and the game ends. Our foe is doomed and all because of my... er... I mean "our" power.
Bah! I still have time to snatch victory from your unworthy hands!
Coward! Come face me on battlefield!
It is all over but the victory parade now. Ha!
I tire of you. Now we will be finished.
The end is near, cur. Grovel before me and I might show mercy. (laughter) Who am I kidding?
Those knaves! Let us seek immediate retribution upon their bodies. They will pay for their insolence!
Too bad. Now I will have to crush you the old-fashioned way.
Ha! I knew you would not be able to pull it off! Now REAL fight begins.
I have crushed your monopoly and now you are mine.
Any last wishes before my army destroys your pathetic colony?
Curse their eyes! The enemy has monopoly. They cannot win with strength, so they are trying with cunning.
Quickly! We must destroy one of the enemy posts or all is lost!
The cowards. They are not worthy of sniffing my boot.
Building trading posts is not the most glorious way to win war, but is certainly effective.
They have to come to us now to keep us from winning. Let us prepare an ambush.
Good, I tire of these curs. Let us be done with them by any means possible.
You would settle for winning that way? I am almost ashamed to be fighting you.
Ha! You cannot believe your trading posts will survive the Russian army!
So... you do not think you can beat me on battlefield. You are right, coward!
Ha! The final nails in your coffin are being hammered right now.
If - and is big if - you have trustworthy heirs, now would be the time to send them away.
The shadow of mighty Russian empire has fallen on your pathetic colony.
The Aztecs are ground to dust beneath my bootheel.
Who can stand before us? Not the Sioux!
The Aztecs are threat to our victory. We must attack!
We should attack the Iroquois before they grow too strong.
We have let the Sioux grow too strong. We must crush them before is too late.
The outlook is grim. The Aztecs cause even bold Cossacks to tremble in saddle.
How did you let this happen? The Iroquois cannot be left to grow so strong.
How can my soldiers face the strange tactics of the Sioux? Tell me! Bah... I see you do not know either.
I can see the end coming for us, but the Aztecs are weak - let us deal them one last blow.
Though is clear we will not win, my scouts report that the Iroquois are vulnerable. One good attack might do them in.
Quickly, we are losing, but the Sioux are compromised. We can take them down with us!
Where are you? We must go faster.
Do not stop. We are almost there.
The time is short, but do not get too excited.
You are close, but you are not there yet.
Gloat now, dog - your time in the new world will not be long.
Don't worry about the clock. It will be over soon enough.
Look at the time. You do not have long to wait.
What happened to you? Now we must start again.
How does it feel to be on the receiving end?
That is what you get for challenging the Spanish.
A bold attempt, but you see my power.
The enemy has a trade monopoly. Wake up your men and put them to work.
They have a trade monopoly. Take down a trading post or you'll taste my lash.
The dogs have created a monopoly. We must take it down quickly.
The timer has started. We must stay alert.
We have a trade monopoly, pet. Can I trust you to watch my back?
Be wary, pet. The timer has started and our enemies are everywhere.
Ah, so the snake rears its ugly head.
You think a trade monopoly will save you from the might of the Spanish?
A trade monopoly? Do you think I will take this lying down?
Now you see the cunning of the Spanish.
Lie back, dog. It will all be over soon.
How do you like that? It would seem your strategy has failed you.
These Aztecs are strong, but not strong enough.
It is time we drove these Iroquois back to their homelands.
The Sioux are on the run. All that remains is to wipe out the survivors.
These Aztecs fight with the strength of many.
The Iroquois have more fight than I expected.
Where do the Sioux get such strength?
These Aztecs are too powerful. We are losing quickly.
The Iroquois are too strong. I fear we may lose.
Where are you pet? These Sioux are overpowering me.
We must not lose to these weaklings. Pull yourself together.
How can these Indians be winning? We need to do better.
These Sioux are not as strong as they appear. We need to try harder, pet.
Well my little upstart, I can't buy our way out of this one.
Well, my little upstart, stick with me and do as I do. Successes like these will become old hat.
You might defeat me this time but understand it won't be easy to do again.
Do not be so certain of your victory that you grow lax in these last moments.
Only one minute until the end. Can you feel the pressure?
If you simply resign you can save yourself the disgrace of waiting out my victory.
A minor setback; we will still be victorious in the end.
Your actions have only delayed the inevitable.
Did you think I would allow you to win in such a manner?
Your countdown has stopped. What other tricks do you have up your sleeve?
We've missed our chance at victory. Let us resign and fight again.
We have some difficult fighting ahead of us, my little upstart. We must be quick about it.
A trade monopoly at last! We will soon put an end to this war.
The Dutch are known for both diplomacy and trade. This will be a fitting victory.
Trying to take the easy way out, eh, my little upstart? I'll put an end to this nonsense.
A victory by diplomacy and trade? I certainly didn't expect anything so civilized from you.
Accept your defeat and just allow this timer to run out in peace.
There. I have dictated the time of your defeat, unless you are made of sterner stuff than I have yet seen.
What do you make of the Aztecs now that their great cities are reduced to smoking rubble?
Our victory over the Iroquois is imminent.
The Sioux fought fiercely, but our victory over them is close at hand.
I am concerned about the Aztecs... they've grown strong while we were not looking.
The Iroquois are all that I have heard and more. They are a dangerous enemy, not to be taken lightly.
What I do not understand about the Sioux would fill volumes, but I know this - they are dangerous!
Feathers and pelts, clubs and arrows - everywhere we turn we see... the Aztecs!
It was a grave strategic mistake to let the Iroquois grow so strong. And now we are paying for it.
The Sioux have met our every attack and come out stronger. It is over for us, my little upstart.
